verses.text: I waited patiently for the LORD, and he turned to me and heard my cry.
verses.comment: The Psalmist expresses trust and persistence in prayer, showing that patience is rewarded when approaching God in faith. Compare also with the attitude of persistent prayer recommended by Christ (see Luke 18:1-8).

verses.text: He lifted me up out of the pit of destruction, out of the miry clay, and set my feet upon a rock, making my steps secure.
verses.comment: The 'pit' and 'miry clay' symbolize sin and despair, while being set upon the rock foreshadows Christ as the foundation. Spiritual interpretation often connects this verse to spiritual rebirth and the security found in Christ's Church (see Matt. 7:24-25).

verses.text: He put a new song in my mouth, a song of praise to our God. Many will see and fear, and put their trust in the LORD.
verses.comment: Praising God leads others to faith. The 'new song' can represent the praises of the redeemed, and also foreshadows the new covenant and the worship the faithful offer to God (see Rev. 14:3).

verses.text: Blessed is the man who makes the LORD his trust, and does not turn to the proud or to those who go astray after lies.
verses.comment: Happiness is found in trusting God alone, avoiding the temptations of pride and falsehood. The theme of spiritual discernment and faithfulness is foundational for understanding Christian obedience.

verses.text: Many, O LORD my God, are the wonders you have done, and your thoughts toward us—none can compare with you. Were I to declare and speak of them, they are more than can be counted.
verses.comment: This verse acknowledges God's providence and wisdom as being beyond human comprehension, a theme echoed in Romans 11:33. The Church has often meditated on the mystery and depth of God’s plan for salvation.

verses.text: Sacrifice and offering you did not desire, but you have opened my ears; burnt offering and sin offering you have not required.
verses.comment: This verse points to inner obedience over mere ritual. Hebrews 10:5-7 quotes this as referring to Christ, whose perfect obedience fulfills the Law. Hearing and responding to God's will is at the heart of Christian worship.

verses.text: Then I said, 'Behold, I come; in the scroll of the book it is written of me.'
verses.comment: Seen as Messianic prophecy, this verse is applied in Hebrews to Jesus, showing the unity of salvation history. God’s plan was foretold and is fulfilled in Christ’s coming.

verses.text: I delight to do your will, O my God; your law is within my heart.
verses.comment: True worship flows from the heart. The internalization of God’s law anticipates the new covenant, in which God writes his law on the hearts of his people (Jer. 31:33; Heb. 10:16).

verses.text: I have proclaimed the good news of righteousness in the great assembly; I have not restrained my lips, as you know, O LORD.
verses.comment: Publicly proclaiming God’s righteousness prefigures Christ's mission and the call for his followers to witness to the truth in the gathered people of God (see Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: I have not hidden your righteousness within my heart; I have spoken of your faithfulness and your salvation; I have not concealed your lovingkindness and your truth from the great assembly.
verses.comment: The Psalmist shows the importance of confessing and sharing faith openly. The term 'great assembly' often points to the gathering of worshipers, which has foundations for Christian liturgical worship.

verses.text: Do not withhold your mercy from me, O LORD; may your lovingkindness and your truth continually guard me.
verses.comment: A prayer for God’s steadfast love and truth reflects the believer's dependence on divine grace for perseverance.

verses.text: For evils without number have surrounded me; my iniquities have overtaken me, and I cannot see; they are more than the hairs of my head, and my heart fails me.
verses.comment: The confession of sin demonstrates humility and the need for continual repentance—core to the life of faith and sacramental practice (see 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: Be pleased, O LORD, to deliver me! O LORD, hurry to help me!
verses.comment: A repeated prayer for deliverance, showing dependence on God for both physical and spiritual rescue. This plea is echoed by the Church in liturgical prayer.

verses.text: Let those who seek to destroy my life be ashamed and confounded together; let those who desire my harm be turned back and humiliated.
verses.comment: Calling for justice against evildoers, the Psalmist entrusts vengeance to God, which upholds the biblical principle of not repaying evil for evil (Rom. 12:19).

verses.text: Let those who say to me, 'Aha! Aha!' be appalled because of their shame.
verses.comment: Mockery and scorn are met with a prayer for vindication. Christ himself was mocked (see Matt. 27:39), and those united to him may share in this suffering.

verses.text: Let all who seek you rejoice and be glad in you; let those who love your salvation continually say, 'The LORD is great!'
verses.comment: Joy and praise belong to those who seek God and love salvation. This verse highlights the communal and liturgical nature of worship, foreshadowing the eternal praise of God by the redeemed.

verses.text: But I am poor and needy; may the Lord think of me. You are my help and my deliverer; O my God, do not delay.
verses.comment: The Psalm concludes in humble supplication, showing the importance of humility and trust in God’s mercy. The repeated phrase underscores both personal need and God's faithfulness to deliver, resonating with the teachings on God’s grace and our continual dependence on Him.
